page.title: 02Landscape:Physical Analysis
page.content: The land slopes gently from west to east from 130 metres in the north west to 76 metres in the east. The annual mean temperature is 12.6 degrees centigrade with January the coldest month and July the warmest. The growing season lasts about 230 days from March to November. The average rainfall is relatively modest (approximately 700 mm per annum) with no clear cut seasonal variation. The soil formation for the whole area is Tinius Keuper Marl, a red, silty clay, apart from a small area of overlain glacial boulder clay or till; a complex mosaic of clay, silt and sand. The vegetation is mainly agricultural, in particular barley and improved grazing, and extensive woodland known as the Burbage Common and Woods. {Nicholas Wood 6W2B
